text: When the toxic environment and the politics within the company were getting all the more complicated. Leaving no room for personal and professional growth and development and eventually I ended spending most of my working day explaining and trying to educate people who wished to remain in denial because it served their toxic behaviour

text:
Hi everyone, I've been working as a freelancer for 2 years now, mostly with non-tech, small businesses and startups.
I’ve realized that almost all of them lack strategy and see marketing just as a Facebook or google ads campaign which brings little to no results. I’ve been trying to create a website and provide marketing strategy services.
I’m in the middle of creating content for my website and feel very overwhelmed with the amount of work it requires.
I’ve been thinking that having a partner or a mentor would be really great, do you have any suggestions or advice for me on how to find a partner or mentor? Really appreciate it!

attachments.text: They say it’ll open doors, it’ll expand your network, they say it will help you grow and succeed and stuff like that. So there’s so much stuff out there about finding a mentor. I’ve read a lot of it…

text:
Depends what you mean by mentoring specifically. I've had a number of people who helped me along, but I think only one (who I currently report to) would be a mentor in the sense that I get a ton of feedback on my work.

When I was starting out, I emailed people who I thought were really good and said "hey, I'm new at this and trying to figure it out. Here are the steps I've already taken. What should I do next?"

Busy people want to know that their advice won't be wasted, so showing the work first got me a bunch of responses

text: Here's kind of an out of the box thought to mull over.  If you ever read the book Million Dollar Consulting (a great read if you're an aspiring strategy consultant), one of the things that he recommends is forming a board of directors for your solo consulting practice.  That's a little ambitious (paying them for quarterly strategy meetups), but with an established website and practice, you could solicit (initially) non-compensated advisors with the idea of eventual compensation.

elements.text: Here's kind of an out of the box thought to mull over.  If you ever read the book Million Dollar Consulting (a great read if you're an aspiring strategy consultant), one of the things that he recommends is forming a board of directors for your solo consulting practice.  That's a little ambitious (paying them for quarterly strategy meetups), but with an established website and practice, you could solicit (initially) non-compensated advisors with the idea of eventual compensation.

text: You might wind up syncing with people who were looking for a foot in the door with their first advisory/board roles, to mutual benefit

text:
A new manager got hired to lead the entire sales team (9/10 were women at the time). He treated all of the women like shit and talked down to everyone, myself included.

After our first awful encounter I had a sit down with my manager to ask if I was being sensitive or if it was worth addressing (first time I’ve ever experienced such a thing). He said, no this is something you should address.

So… I booked a 1-1 with the new sales manager and straight up asked him if he thought I was incompetent. I shared my feelings on why I thought his actions were super inappropriate against me and other women in the company.

He didn’t change. I brought it up with several leaders in the company, including the CEO. Senior leaders had their hands tied because ultimately it was the CEO’s choice (sales manager was his friend.. surprise surprise).

After a month, still nothing got done, so I quit (along with the entire sales time) because the culture was _so_ toxic that it affected my personal life so much.

text: I found a career coach through LinkedIn. Maybe you could put that experience in your request and find someone specific to that field.

text:
Hey <@UUXMJMU95> great question! Personally I haven't explicitly asked people to mentor me. I just network a lot and build rapport and every so often bounce ideas off them and vice versa.

It's hard for me to explain, but I will say asking "can you mentor me," can be offputting because it sounds like a massive time commitment.

Usually when I meet someone interesting I say "let's keep in touch" and reach out every so often.

For me personally, I'm more than willing to have coffee chats with other professionals to share advice, but if they asked for "mentorship" I'd be weary because I feel like that term provides a premise that I can consistently dedicate time to help the person grow.

This episode of the Tim Ferris podcast might be helpful. I'm a huge fan: <https://tim.blog/2019/03/11/tea-time-with-tim/>

attachments.service_name: The Blog of Author Tim Ferriss
attachments.title: Tea Time with Tim — How to Find Mentors, Decrease Anxiety Through Training, and Much More (#363)
attachments.text: Welcome to a special episode called “Tea Time with Tim,” for which I solicited phone numbers and then called a handful of you to field any questions you might have. Among other topics, …
attachments.fallback: The Blog of Author Tim Ferriss: Tea Time with Tim — How to Find Mentors, Decrease Anxiety Through Training, and Much More (#363)

For me personally, I'm more than willing to have coffee chats with other professionals to share advice, but if they asked for "mentorship" I'd be weary because I feel like that term provides a premise that I can consistently dedicate time to help the person grow.

text:
I’ve pondered a job transition many times. The occasions largely fall into two categories:
1-I’m scared and think a new gig will be better/safer/scratch an itch/be easier/any other lie that fear drives you to believe.
(Fear of failure and fear of success are very similar in my experience.)
2-The current situation is untenable.
Whether that’s a terrible culture/hierarchy;
or it’s not a bad _place_, it’s just a bad _fit_;
or I am having semi-regular panic attacks.
(Sadly, there are many examples of this category listed above.)

If it’s the first, address the source of the fear. Battle it. Take it out back and end its miserable existence. It’s a process--a sometimes excruciating one--but worthwhile. Afterwards, survey the grasses. Is yours greener now?
If it’s the second, update your résumé.
(Overhaul it if you need to.)
Put together your book/portfolio.
Look at your best work.
Look at your favorite work.
(Maybe there’s overlap, maybe not.) Analyze it. Why are you proud? What do yo love about it? What are the commonalities you didn’t see before? This process always reminds me of my value and my interests and my strengths. Dig deep and poke around.

Now you’ve got your personal value prop, a great looking CV, a confidence boost, and clarity about what you want.

Take all that information and lay it down on the table next to your current job.
Does it match up?
Yes? :arrow_right: You’re probably in a good spot; just needed some objectivity. Keep working hard and reassess down the road.
No? :arrow_heading_down:
Could you and the leadership reshape it to match up?
Yes? :arrow_right: Rock n’ Roll! Stay  and build something new and exciting. It could benefit you and the whole org.
No? :arrow_heading_down:
      Bounce.
Find something that can stand up and take the heat from this newly-stoked fire of confidence and vision.

In short,
1. Search your soul.
2. Listen carefully to your honest self.
3. Objectively analyze and synthesize your work and your strengths.
4. Don’t sell yourself short. 
(Simple, right? :wink:)
